questions.question: Data sent over long distances is divided into small units called ________ to make transmission easier to control.
Which statement is supported by the notes about using packets?
options: Packets force data to use a single fixed route end-to-end
Packets allow different routes to be used if one route is unsuitable
Packets remove the need to reassemble data at the destination
Packets require one continuous data stream for reliability
questions.answer: Packets allow different routes to be used if one route is unsuitable

questions.question: Packets are reassembled at the destination into the original message.
Datagrams is another word for packets.
Match each packet part to its role.

pairs.Header: Contains addressing and control information, including information about any error-checking methods that may be used
pairs.Payload: Actual data carried by the packet; size is not fixed and depends on technology or protocol
pairs.Trailer: Marks the end; includes an error-detection value that the receiver recomputes

questions.question: The __________ contains source/destination IP addresses and sequencing information, while the __________ is the actual data being carried.
What happens when the hop limit in a packet header reaches zero before delivery?
options: The packet is automatically resent with a new limit
The packet is discarded
The packet is converted to a different protocol
The packet bypasses all remaining routers

questions.question: The __________ marks the end of the packet and includes error-checking methods such as cyclic redundancy check (CRC).
Which header details are listed in the notes in addition to IP addresses?
options: Only the actual data being transmitted
Error checking methods and end-of-packet markers
Protocol identification and sequencing information
The total size of all packets in the transmission

questions.question: ________ switching is a method of transmitting data packets independently along network paths, then placing them back in the correct order at the destination using header information.
How do routers choose the next route for packets according to the notes?
options: They always use the absolute shortest path available
They randomly select from available paths
They choose based on current conditions such as queue lengths, selecting a shortest available path
They follow a predetermined sequence set by the sender
questions.answer: They choose based on current conditions such as queue lengths, selecting a shortest available path

questions.question: Packets can arrive out of order, and the destination system reorders them correctly.
Which is listed as a drawback or overhead of packet switching in the notes?
options: It ties up a single dedicated line for the whole message
It removes all delays caused by reordering
It can introduce delays from reordering and challenges for real-time streaming
It prevents retransmission of missing or corrupted packets
questions.answer: It can introduce delays from reordering and challenges for real-time streaming

questions.question: What happens when a packet is missing or corrupted at the destination?
options: The entire message is discarded and must be resent
The destination requests that specific packet again
The missing packet is ignored and the message continues
A new route is automatically established for all future packets
questions.answer: The destination requests that specific packet again

questions.question: Match each mode to its direction property.

pairs.simplex: One direction only from sender to receiver
pairs.half-duplex: Both directions, but not at the same time
pairs.full-duplex: Both directions at the same time

questions.question: Which statement matches the notes?
options: Serial sends several bits at the same time over multiple wires
Parallel sends one bit at a time over a single wire or channel
Serial sends one bit at a time over a single wire or channel
Parallel guarantees long-distance reliability at lower data rates than serial
questions.answer: Serial sends one bit at a time over a single wire or channel

questions.question: In the notes, ________ transmission sends several bits at the same time over multiple wires, for example a byte.
Which transmission method allows bidirectional communication but not simultaneously?
options: Simplex
Full-duplex
Parallel
Half-duplex

questions.question: Which mode allows data to be sent in both directions at the same time?
options: simplex
half-duplex
full-duplex
parallel

questions.question: Which choice fits the notes for long-distance links with lower cost and maintained synchronisation at lower data rates?
options: Parallel transmission
Serial transmission
Full-duplex only
Half-duplex only

questions.question: According to the notes, ________ transmission is preferred for short distances and time-critical tasks because it is faster, but it needs more hardware and is therefore more expensive.
The notes say that parallel is generally less expensive than serial for long-distance transmission.
Which feature is explicitly listed as a benefit in the notes?
options: Guaranteed faster file transfer than Ethernet
Provision of a +5 volt power supply through the cable
Unlimited cable length without signal loss
No need to share bandwidth between connected devices
questions.answer: Provision of a +5 volt power supply through the cable

questions.question: What is a listed benefit of USB automatic device detection?
options: It reduces cable length requirements
It provides setup without manual configuration
It increases data transfer speeds
It eliminates the need for power supply
questions.answer: It provides setup without manual configuration

questions.question: For error handling, the USB protocol requires the sender to re-send data until errors are detected to be absent, so that the final received data is ________.
USB uses __________ data transfer and can operate in half-duplex or __________ modes.
Which statement from the notes describes USB-C?
options: A legacy connector that is not backward compatible
A 24-pin symmetrical connector that can be inserted either way and remains backward compatible when a suitable adaptor is used
A connector limited to one orientation and incompatible with older USB devices
A connector that carries no power
questions.answer: A 24-pin symmetrical connector that can be inserted either way and remains backward compatible when a suitable adaptor is used

questions.question: Match each statement to category.
What power delivery capability does USB-C support according to the notes?
options: Up to about 50 watts at 10 volts
Up to about 100 watts at 20 volts
Up to about 200 watts at 40 volts
Fixed 5 volts only like standard USB
questions.answer: Up to about 100 watts at 20 volts

questions.question: USB-C supports high-resolution video such as 4K while remaining backward compatible when a suitable adaptor is used.
